'''Necrophilia''', also called '''thanatophilia ''' and '''necrolagnia''', is a [[paraphilia]] characterized by a [[human sexuality|sexual]] attraction to [[corpse]]s. The word is artificially derived from Ancient Greek: ''Î½ÎµÎºÏÏÏ '' (''nekros''; "corpse," or "dead") and ÏÎ¹Î»Î¯Î± (''philia''; "love"). The term appears<ref name="litera">{{ru icon}} [http://www.litera.ru/slova/gorny/necro.html "ÐÐÐÐ ÐÐ¤ÐÐÐÐ¯ ÐÐÐ Ð¡Ð¢Ð Ð£ÐÐ¢Ð£Ð Ð Ð¡ÐÐÐÐÐÐÐ¯"], 2002.</ref> to have originated from [[Richard Freiherr von Krafft-Ebing|Krafft-Ebing]]'s 1886 work ''[[Psychopathia Sexualis]]''.<ref>Krafft-Ebing, Richard von (1886). ''Psychopathia Sexualis''. English translation: ISBN 1-55970-425-X.</ref>
â
Figuratively, the term "necrophilia" describes an inordinate desire to control another person, usually in the context of a [[romantic love| romantic]] or interpersonal relationship; the accusation is that the person is so interpersonally controlling as to be better-suited to relationships with nonresponsive people.{{fact}}
+
Figuratively, the term "necrophilia" describes an inordinate desire to control another person, usually in the context of a [[romantic love|romantic]] or interpersonal relationship; the accusation is that the person is so interpersonally controlling as to be better-suited to relationships with nonresponsive people.{{fact}}
==Social, legal and psychological views on necrophilia==
